_link.title: I can recall and define the terms fluid mosaic model, hydrophilic, hydrophobic, plasma membrane and semi-permeable membrane

options.text: Water-attracting
options.explanation: Hydrophilic means water-attracting. The phospholipid heads of the plasma membrane are hydrophilic and face towards the watery environments.

options.text: Water-repelling
options.explanation: Water-repelling is the definition of hydrophobic, not hydrophilic.

options.text: Fat-dissolving
options.explanation: Hydrophilic refers to an attraction to water, not to dissolving fats.

options.text: Heat-absorbing
options.explanation: Hydrophilic relates to water affinity, not heat absorption.

toLevel2.question: What does the fluid mosaic model describe?

options.text: The plasma membrane as a mix of moving phospholipids, proteins and other molecules
options.explanation: The fluid mosaic model describes the plasma membrane as a combination of phospholipids, proteins, cholesterol, and carbohydrates that can move within each layer.

options.text: The structure of the cell wall in plant cells only
options.explanation: The fluid mosaic model describes the plasma membrane, not the cell wall.

options.text: The arrangement of organelles inside the cytoplasm
options.explanation: The fluid mosaic model specifically describes the structure of the plasma membrane, not the organisation of organelles.

options.text: The flow of water through a fully permeable membrane
options.explanation: The fluid mosaic model describes the structure of the semi-permeable plasma membrane, not water flow through a fully permeable one.

options.text: A semi-permeable phospholipid bilayer surrounding the cell
options.explanation: The plasma membrane is a semi-permeable phospholipid bilayer that separates the internal and external environments of a cell.

options.text: A rigid outer wall that provides structural support
options.explanation: A rigid outer wall describes the cell wall, not the plasma membrane. The plasma membrane is flexible.

options.text: A fully permeable layer that allows all substances through
options.explanation: The plasma membrane is semi-permeable, meaning it selectively allows certain substances to pass through.

options.text: A protein coat found only on animal cell surfaces
options.explanation: The plasma membrane is a phospholipid bilayer found in all cells, not just animal cells, and is not a protein coat.

options.text: Water-repelling
options.explanation: Hydrophobic means water-repelling. The fatty acid tails of phospholipids are hydrophobic and face inward, away from water.

options.text: Water-attracting
options.explanation: Water-attracting is the definition of hydrophilic, not hydrophobic.

options.text: Water-absorbing
options.explanation: Hydrophobic substances repel water rather than absorbing it.

options.text: Water-producing
options.explanation: Hydrophobic refers to repelling water, not producing it.

toLevel2.question: What does 'semi-permeable' mean when describing the plasma membrane?

options.text: It allows some substances to pass through but not others
options.explanation: Semi-permeable means the membrane selectively allows certain substances to cross while blocking others.

options.text: It blocks all substances from crossing the membrane
options.explanation: A membrane that blocks all substances would be impermeable, not semi-permeable.

options.text: It allows all substances to pass through freely
options.explanation: A membrane that allows everything through would be fully permeable, not semi-permeable.

options.text: It only functions in one direction at a time
options.explanation: Semi-permeable refers to selectivity of substances, not the direction of transport.

toLevel2.question: The phospholipid heads of the plasma membrane are hydrophilic and face towards the watery environments on both sides of the membrane.
toLevel2.explanation: Phospholipid heads are hydrophilic (water-attracting) and are oriented towards the aqueous environments on both the inside and outside of the cell.

options.text: True
False

toLevel2.question: The fatty acid tails of phospholipids are hydrophilic and face outward towards water.
toLevel2.explanation: The fatty acid tails are hydrophobic (water-repelling) and face inward, away from the watery environments on both sides of the membrane.

options.text: True
False

toLevel2.question: The plasma membrane is described by the {{blank:1}} model as a mix of phospholipids, proteins and other molecules that can {{blank:2}} within each layer.
Phospholipid heads are {{blank:1}} and face towards water, while the fatty acid tails are {{blank:2}} and face away from water.
The plasma membrane is a {{blank:1}} phospholipid bilayer, meaning it allows {{blank:2}} substances to pass through but not others.

toLevel3.question: Why are the fatty acid tails of phospholipids arranged facing inward in the plasma membrane?

options.text: Because they are hydrophobic and are repelled by the watery environments on both sides
options.explanation: The hydrophobic fatty acid tails are repelled by water and face inward to avoid contact with the aqueous environments on both sides of the membrane.

options.text: Because they need to absorb water from inside the cell to maintain membrane structure
options.explanation: Hydrophobic tails repel water; they do not absorb it. Their inward orientation minimises contact with water.

options.text: Because they are attracted to the proteins embedded in the centre of the membrane
options.explanation: The tails face inward due to their hydrophobic nature, not because of attraction to membrane proteins.

options.text: Because they are too large to fit on the outer surface of the membrane structure
options.explanation: The inward orientation is due to hydrophobic interactions with water, not the physical size of the tails.

toLevel3.question: Explain why the plasma membrane is described as 'fluid' in the fluid mosaic model.

options.text: Because phospholipids and proteins can move laterally within the membrane layers
options.explanation: The membrane is described as fluid because its components, including phospholipids and proteins, are not fixed in place and can move laterally within each layer.

options.text: Because the membrane is made entirely of liquid water molecules arranged in layers
options.explanation: The membrane is made of phospholipids, proteins, cholesterol, and carbohydrates, not water molecules.

options.text: Because the membrane dissolves substances that pass through it into a fluid state
options.explanation: The term fluid refers to the movement of membrane components, not the dissolving of substances.

options.text: Because the membrane can change from a solid to a liquid state depending on temperature
options.explanation: While temperature affects membrane fluidity, the term fluid refers to the lateral movement of components within the bilayer.

toLevel3.question: Why is the plasma membrane described as a 'mosaic'?

options.text: Because it contains a varied pattern of different molecules embedded in the bilayer
options.explanation: The term mosaic refers to the diverse mix of phospholipids, proteins, cholesterol, and carbohydrates that create a varied pattern across the membrane surface.

options.text: Because it is made of identical repeating units arranged in a fixed grid pattern
options.explanation: The membrane is not a fixed grid of identical units; it is a diverse mixture of different molecules, hence the term mosaic.

options.text: Because it is composed of small coloured tiles visible under a light microscope always
options.explanation: The term mosaic is an analogy for the varied molecular composition, not a description of visible coloured tiles.

options.text: Because it can be broken into pieces and reassembled like a puzzle without losing function
options.explanation: Mosaic refers to the diverse arrangement of molecules within the membrane, not the ability to break apart and reassemble.

toLevel3.question: How does the semi-permeable nature of the plasma membrane benefit the cell?

options.text: It allows the cell to control which substances enter and leave, maintaining internal conditions
options.explanation: Semi-permeability allows the cell to selectively regulate the passage of substances, maintaining the internal environment needed for cellular processes.

options.text: It prevents all chemical reactions from occurring outside the cell boundary at all times
options.explanation: Semi-permeability controls substance movement across the membrane but does not prevent reactions outside the cell.

options.text: It ensures that water cannot enter or leave the cell under any circumstances at all
options.explanation: Water can cross the semi-permeable membrane through osmosis; the membrane does not block water entirely.

options.text: It makes the membrane rigid enough to protect the cell from all physical damage constantly
options.explanation: Semi-permeability relates to selective substance transport, not physical rigidity or protection from damage.

toLevel3.question: A molecule is described as hydrophilic. What does this tell you about how it interacts with the plasma membrane?

options.text: It cannot easily pass through the hydrophobic interior of the phospholipid bilayer
options.explanation: Hydrophilic molecules are water-attracting and are repelled by the hydrophobic fatty acid tails in the interior of the bilayer, making direct passage difficult.

options.text: It passes freely through the centre of the membrane without any assistance needed
options.explanation: Hydrophilic molecules cannot easily cross the hydrophobic interior and typically require transport proteins.

options.text: It dissolves the phospholipid bilayer upon contact and enters the cell immediately
options.explanation: Hydrophilic molecules do not dissolve the membrane; they interact with the hydrophilic surface but cannot easily cross the hydrophobic core.

options.text: It is repelled by the membrane surface and cannot approach the cell at all under any condition
options.explanation: Hydrophilic molecules are attracted to the hydrophilic phospholipid heads on the membrane surface but cannot easily pass through the hydrophobic interior.

toLevel3.question: What role does cholesterol play in the plasma membrane according to the fluid mosaic model?

options.text: It helps regulate membrane fluidity by stabilising the phospholipid bilayer
options.explanation: Cholesterol is embedded between phospholipids and helps maintain membrane fluidity by preventing the fatty acid tails from packing too closely or moving too freely.

options.text: It forms the primary structural framework that replaces all phospholipids in the membrane
options.explanation: Cholesterol does not replace phospholipids; it is interspersed among them to regulate fluidity.

options.text: It acts as the main transport protein for moving substances across the membrane actively
options.explanation: Cholesterol is a lipid, not a protein. Transport proteins are separate molecules that facilitate substance movement.

options.text: It provides energy for active transport processes occurring across the plasma membrane
options.explanation: Cholesterol regulates membrane structure and fluidity; ATP provides the energy for active transport.

toLevel3.question: In the fluid mosaic model, the membrane components are fixed in place and cannot move within the bilayer.
toLevel3.explanation: The fluid mosaic model describes the membrane as fluid, meaning phospholipids and proteins can move laterally within each layer of the bilayer.

options.text: True
False

toLevel3.question: Hydrophilic molecules cannot easily pass through the {{blank:1}} interior of the phospholipid {{blank:2}}.
The membrane is called a 'mosaic' because it contains a {{blank:1}} mix of phospholipids, proteins, cholesterol and {{blank:2}}.
Cholesterol is embedded between {{blank:1}} in the membrane to help regulate {{blank:2}}.

toLevel4.question: A student claims that a hydrophobic molecule would have difficulty crossing the plasma membrane. Is this claim correct?

options.text: No, hydrophobic molecules pass easily through the hydrophobic interior of the bilayer
options.explanation: Hydrophobic molecules are compatible with the hydrophobic fatty acid tails in the membrane interior and can pass through the bilayer relatively easily.

options.text: Yes, hydrophobic molecules are repelled by all parts of the plasma membrane equally
options.explanation: Hydrophobic molecules are repelled by the hydrophilic heads but are compatible with the hydrophobic interior, allowing them to cross.

options.text: Yes, only hydrophilic molecules can cross the plasma membrane under any conditions at all
options.explanation: Both hydrophilic and hydrophobic molecules can cross the membrane, but through different mechanisms. Hydrophobic molecules can pass directly through the bilayer.

options.text: No, but only because transport proteins carry hydrophobic molecules across the membrane
options.explanation: Hydrophobic molecules can cross directly through the lipid bilayer without needing transport proteins because they are compatible with the hydrophobic interior.

toLevel4.question: Apply the fluid mosaic model to explain why the plasma membrane can reseal after a small puncture.

options.text: Because phospholipids are fluid and can move to fill gaps in the bilayer
options.explanation: The fluid nature of the membrane allows phospholipids to move laterally, enabling them to flow towards and seal small disruptions in the bilayer.

options.text: Because the membrane is rigid and snaps back into its original shape like a solid material
options.explanation: The membrane is fluid, not rigid. Its ability to reseal comes from the lateral movement of phospholipids, not from elastic rigidity.

options.text: Because proteins in the membrane actively pull the edges of the puncture together using ATP
options.explanation: Resealing occurs through the spontaneous movement of phospholipids due to their fluid nature, not through active protein-mediated pulling.

options.text: Because cholesterol fills the puncture site and forms a permanent solid patch over the damage
options.explanation: Cholesterol helps regulate fluidity but does not form solid patches. Resealing involves the lateral movement of phospholipids.

toLevel4.question: A cell is placed in a solution containing both hydrophilic and hydrophobic molecules. Which molecules would you expect to cross the membrane more easily without transport proteins?

options.text: Hydrophobic molecules, because they can pass through the hydrophobic bilayer interior
options.explanation: Hydrophobic molecules are compatible with the hydrophobic fatty acid tails and can diffuse directly through the bilayer without assistance.

options.text: Hydrophilic molecules, because the membrane surface is hydrophilic and attracts them inside
options.explanation: While the membrane surface is hydrophilic, hydrophilic molecules cannot easily pass through the hydrophobic interior without transport proteins.

options.text: Both types cross equally easily because the membrane is semi-permeable to all molecules
options.explanation: Semi-permeable means selective; the hydrophobic interior of the bilayer favours the passage of hydrophobic molecules over hydrophilic ones.

options.text: Neither type can cross without transport proteins because the membrane blocks all direct passage
options.explanation: Small hydrophobic molecules can cross the bilayer directly without transport proteins due to their compatibility with the hydrophobic interior.

toLevel4.question: A student draws a plasma membrane diagram with phospholipid tails facing outward. What error have they made?

options.text: The hydrophobic tails should face inward, away from the aqueous environments
options.explanation: Phospholipid tails are hydrophobic and should face inward in the bilayer, away from the water on both sides of the membrane.

options.text: The diagram is correct because tails always face the external environment of the cell
options.explanation: The hydrophobic tails face inward towards each other, not outward. The hydrophilic heads face the aqueous environments.

options.text: The tails should be removed entirely because phospholipids only have heads in the membrane
options.explanation: Phospholipids have both hydrophilic heads and hydrophobic tails; both are essential components of the bilayer structure.

options.text: The error is that there should be three layers of phospholipids, not just two in the membrane
options.explanation: The plasma membrane is a bilayer (two layers) of phospholipids, with tails facing inward and heads facing outward.

toLevel4.question: How would removing all cholesterol from a plasma membrane affect its properties?

options.text: The membrane would become less stable and its fluidity would be poorly regulated
options.explanation: Cholesterol helps stabilise the membrane by preventing phospholipid tails from packing too tightly or moving too freely. Without it, fluidity regulation would be impaired.

options.text: The membrane would become completely impermeable to all substances without exception
options.explanation: Removing cholesterol would affect fluidity regulation but would not make the membrane completely impermeable.

options.text: The membrane would function normally because cholesterol is not an essential membrane component
options.explanation: Cholesterol plays an important role in regulating membrane fluidity and stability; its removal would affect membrane function.

options.text: The membrane would immediately dissolve because cholesterol is the main structural component
options.explanation: Phospholipids are the main structural component of the membrane. Cholesterol regulates fluidity but is not the primary structural element.

toLevel4.question: Apply the concept of semi-permeability to explain why a cell can maintain a different internal concentration of ions compared to its external environment.

options.text: The membrane selectively controls ion passage using transport proteins and the hydrophobic barrier
options.explanation: Ions are charged and hydrophilic, so they cannot freely cross the hydrophobic bilayer. The semi-permeable membrane uses transport proteins to selectively control ion movement.

options.text: The membrane allows all ions to pass freely in both directions at all times without restriction
options.explanation: If ions could pass freely, the cell could not maintain different internal and external concentrations. Semi-permeability restricts free passage.

options.text: The membrane blocks all ions permanently, so concentrations never change inside the cell at all
options.explanation: The membrane does allow controlled ion movement through transport proteins; it does not block all ions permanently.

options.text: Ions are hydrophobic and can pass through the membrane core without any assistance from proteins
options.explanation: Ions are charged and hydrophilic, meaning they cannot easily cross the hydrophobic interior of the bilayer without transport proteins.

toLevel4.question: Why is the fluid mosaic model considered a better description of the plasma membrane than a simple 'sandwich' model?

options.text: It accounts for the movement of components and the diverse molecular composition of the membrane
options.explanation: The fluid mosaic model captures both the lateral movement of molecules and the varied composition of the membrane, which a static sandwich model cannot represent.

options.text: The sandwich model is more accurate because the membrane is rigid and has only two fixed layers
options.explanation: The membrane is not rigid; its components move laterally. The fluid mosaic model better represents this dynamic behaviour.

options.text: The fluid mosaic model was proposed first and therefore has historical priority over the sandwich model
options.explanation: The fluid mosaic model replaced earlier models because it better explains observed membrane behaviour, not because of historical priority.

options.text: Both models describe the membrane equally well and there is no scientific reason to prefer one model
options.explanation: The fluid mosaic model is supported by more evidence and accounts for dynamic molecular movement, making it the accepted model.

toLevel4.question: Hydrophobic molecules can cross the plasma membrane directly because they are compatible with the {{blank:1}} fatty acid {{blank:2}} in the bilayer interior.
The plasma membrane can reseal after a small puncture because phospholipids are {{blank:1}} and can move {{blank:2}} to fill gaps.
Ions are {{blank:1}} and cannot easily cross the {{blank:2}} interior of the phospholipid bilayer without transport proteins.

toLevel5.question: Evaluate the claim: 'The plasma membrane is semi-permeable, therefore no hydrophilic molecules can ever cross it.'

options.text: The claim is incorrect because hydrophilic molecules can cross via transport proteins embedded in the membrane
options.explanation: Semi-permeable means selective, not impenetrable. Transport proteins in the membrane facilitate the passage of hydrophilic molecules that cannot cross the hydrophobic bilayer directly.

options.text: The claim is correct because semi-permeable means only hydrophobic molecules are allowed to cross at all
options.explanation: Semi-permeable does not mean only hydrophobic molecules can cross. Transport proteins allow hydrophilic molecules to pass through the membrane.

options.text: The claim is correct because the hydrophilic heads block all hydrophilic molecules from approaching the surface
options.explanation: The hydrophilic heads attract hydrophilic molecules to the surface; it is the hydrophobic interior that blocks direct passage, which transport proteins can overcome.

options.text: The claim is incorrect because all molecules can freely cross a semi-permeable membrane without any restriction
options.explanation: Semi-permeable means selective, not freely permeable. The membrane controls which molecules can cross and often requires transport proteins for hydrophilic molecules.

toLevel5.question: Analyse how the arrangement of hydrophilic and hydrophobic regions in the phospholipid bilayer creates a selective barrier.

options.text: The hydrophobic interior repels charged and polar molecules while allowing nonpolar molecules to pass through
options.explanation: The hydrophobic fatty acid tails create an interior that repels hydrophilic (polar and charged) molecules but is compatible with hydrophobic (nonpolar) molecules, creating selectivity.

options.text: The hydrophilic heads block all molecules from reaching the membrane surface regardless of polarity
options.explanation: The hydrophilic heads attract polar molecules to the surface; it is the hydrophobic interior that provides selectivity by blocking polar molecules from crossing.

options.text: Both regions are equally permeable to all molecules so selectivity comes only from membrane thickness
options.explanation: Selectivity arises from the chemical properties of the hydrophilic and hydrophobic regions, not from membrane thickness alone.

options.text: The hydrophobic tails attract all molecules equally, making the membrane freely permeable to everything
options.explanation: Hydrophobic tails repel polar and charged molecules while allowing nonpolar molecules to pass, creating selective permeability.

toLevel5.question: Compare the roles of phospholipids and proteins in the fluid mosaic model. Which statement best describes their complementary functions?

options.text: Phospholipids form the structural barrier while proteins provide specific transport and signalling functions
options.explanation: Phospholipids create the semi-permeable bilayer barrier, while proteins embedded in the membrane carry out specific functions including transport, enzymatic activity, and cell signalling.

options.text: Proteins form the structural barrier while phospholipids provide transport and signalling functions
options.explanation: This reverses the roles: phospholipids form the bilayer barrier, and proteins provide the specialised functional roles.

options.text: Both phospholipids and proteins perform identical functions and are completely interchangeable in the membrane
options.explanation: Phospholipids and proteins have distinct roles; phospholipids provide structure while proteins provide specific functions.

options.text: Phospholipids are found only on the outer surface while proteins are found only on the inner surface
options.explanation: Phospholipids form both layers of the bilayer, and proteins can be found on either surface or spanning the entire membrane.

toLevel5.question: A researcher observes that a drug designed to treat a disease cannot cross the plasma membrane. The drug is water-soluble. Suggest why this occurs and how it might be overcome.

options.text: The water-soluble drug is hydrophilic and is blocked by the hydrophobic bilayer interior; a protein carrier could help
options.explanation: Water-soluble molecules are hydrophilic and cannot easily cross the hydrophobic interior of the bilayer. Using a transport protein or lipid-based delivery system could facilitate passage.

options.text: The drug is too large to fit between the phospholipid heads, so making it smaller would solve the problem
options.explanation: The primary barrier for water-soluble drugs is the hydrophobic interior, not the spacing between phospholipid heads. Size reduction alone may not help.

options.text: Water-soluble drugs always cross membranes easily, so the membrane must be damaged and needs repair
options.explanation: Water-soluble (hydrophilic) drugs cannot easily cross the hydrophobic bilayer interior; this is normal membrane function, not damage.

options.text: The drug is hydrophobic and needs to be made more water-soluble to cross the hydrophilic membrane core
options.explanation: The drug is described as water-soluble (hydrophilic). The membrane core is hydrophobic, which blocks hydrophilic molecules.

toLevel5.question: Evaluate how the fluid mosaic model explains the ability of cells to change shape during processes like cell division.

options.text: The fluid nature allows phospholipids to rearrange and the membrane to deform without breaking apart
options.explanation: Because phospholipids can move laterally within the bilayer, the membrane is flexible enough to change shape during cell division without losing its structural integrity.

options.text: The membrane is rigid and must completely dissolve and reform each time the cell changes shape
options.explanation: The membrane is fluid, not rigid. It can deform and reshape through lateral movement of its components without dissolving.

options.text: Cell shape changes are impossible according to the fluid mosaic model because the membrane is fixed
options.explanation: The fluid mosaic model explicitly accounts for membrane flexibility; the fluid nature of the bilayer allows shape changes.

options.text: Only the proteins move during cell division while the phospholipids remain completely stationary in place
options.explanation: Both phospholipids and proteins can move within the membrane, contributing to its flexibility during cell division.

toLevel5.question: Analyse why the term 'semi-permeable' is more scientifically accurate than 'selectively permeable' for describing the plasma membrane.

options.text: Both terms are used interchangeably in biology; semi-permeable emphasises partial permeability while selectively permeable emphasises active control
options.explanation: Both terms describe the same property. Semi-permeable highlights that the membrane allows some but not all substances through, while selectively permeable emphasises the cell's active control over transport.

options.text: Semi-permeable is incorrect and should never be used because the membrane is fully permeable to all molecules
options.explanation: The membrane is not fully permeable; it selectively allows certain substances to pass, which is accurately described by both terms.

options.text: Selectively permeable is wrong because the membrane has no control over which substances cross it at all
options.explanation: The membrane does control substance movement through transport proteins and the hydrophobic barrier, so selectively permeable is a valid term.

options.text: Semi-permeable means the membrane works only half the time, which is why selectively permeable is preferred
options.explanation: Semi-permeable does not mean the membrane works half the time; it means the membrane allows some substances through while blocking others.

toLevel5.question: A student argues that since the plasma membrane is described as fluid, it must be unstable and unable to maintain cell structure. Evaluate this reasoning.

options.text: This is incorrect because fluidity allows flexibility while cholesterol and protein interactions maintain structural stability
options.explanation: The membrane is fluid but not unstable. Cholesterol regulates fluidity, and interactions between membrane components maintain structural integrity while allowing necessary flexibility.

options.text: This is correct because fluid substances cannot form stable structures under any conditions in biology
options.explanation: Many biological structures, including the plasma membrane, are fluid yet stable. The bilayer structure is maintained by hydrophobic interactions between fatty acid tails.

options.text: This is correct because the cell wall is the only structure that maintains cell shape and the membrane contributes nothing
options.explanation: While cell walls provide additional support in some cells, the plasma membrane itself is structurally stable due to phospholipid interactions and cholesterol.

options.text: This is incorrect because the membrane is actually completely rigid and the fluid mosaic model is outdated now
options.explanation: The fluid mosaic model is the current accepted model. The membrane is indeed fluid, but this does not make it unstable.

toLevel5.question: Compare how a small nonpolar molecule and a large charged ion would each interact with the plasma membrane when attempting to cross it.

options.text: The nonpolar molecule crosses directly through the bilayer while the charged ion requires a transport protein
options.explanation: Small nonpolar (hydrophobic) molecules pass directly through the hydrophobic interior. Large charged ions are hydrophilic and repelled by the interior, requiring transport proteins.

options.text: Both cross the membrane at the same rate because the membrane is semi-permeable to all substances equally
options.explanation: Semi-permeable means selective; nonpolar molecules cross more easily than charged ions, which need transport proteins.

options.text: The charged ion crosses more easily because it is attracted to the hydrophilic phospholipid heads on the surface
options.explanation: While charged ions are attracted to the surface, they cannot cross the hydrophobic interior without transport proteins.

options.text: Neither can cross the membrane because both are blocked by the phospholipid bilayer under all conditions
options.explanation: Small nonpolar molecules can cross the bilayer directly due to their compatibility with the hydrophobic interior.

toLevel5.question: The fluid mosaic model explains membrane flexibility because {{blank:1}} can move laterally, while {{blank:2}} helps maintain structural stability.
A water-soluble drug cannot cross the membrane because it is {{blank:1}} and is blocked by the {{blank:2}} bilayer interior.
